The guidelines formally  adopted  by  the Independent  Evaluation  Department  (IED)  on  avoiding 
conflict of interest in its independent evaluations were observed in the preparation of this report. 
To  the  knowledge  of  IED  management,  there  were  no  conflicts  of  interest  of  the  persons 
preparing, reviewing, or approving this report. The final ratings are the ratings of IED and may or 
may not coincide with those originally proposed by the consultants engaged for this report. 

In preparing any evaluation report, or by making any designation of or reference to a particular 
territory or geographic area in this document, IED does not intend to make any judgments as to 
the legal or other status of any territory or area.

N. Subramaniam, IESP
T. Ueda, Principal Evaluation Specialist, IESP*

I.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION

A.

Rationale

1.
At appraisal, Sindh’s second-tier cities were under increasing stress of population growth
and urban  poverty.  Deteriorating  urban services added  to  business  costs,  damaged the  urban
environment,  diminished  the  quality  of  life,  and  discouraged  potential  investment.  Previous
attempts  to  improve  the  provision  of  services  were  hindered  by  overlap  and  fragmentation  of

 2 

 

responsibilities  between  the  taluka 1 municipal  administrations  (TMAs)  and  provincial-level 
agencies.  Alternative  approaches  to  service  provision,  including  infrastructure  planning  and 
construction, were needed to address these constraints, particularly, the need to separate service 
delivery from system regulation and political interests to enhance commercial viability. 2   
 
2. 
The multitranche financing facility (MFF) modality was considered appropriate in the report 
and recommendation of the President (RRP)3 since it could help establish a long-term (10-year) 
partnership  between  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  Government  of  Sindh. 4  
This,  in  turn,  could  help  provide  the  opportunity  to  revitalize  Sindh’s  second-tier  cities,  thus, 
facilitating the development of a broad platform for engaging the government on core reforms. 
The  investment  program  was  to  be  anchored  within  a  holistic  and  integrated  service  delivery 
reform  agenda  comprising  (i)  an  enabling  policy  framework  for  service  delivery  reform,  
(ii)  effective  institutions  and  professional  management,  and  (iii)  sustainable  financing  of  urban 
service provision. These key reform milestones were to trigger the release of the first, second, 
and subsequent tranches of the investment loan.   

Expected Impacts, Outcomes, and Outputs 

 
First-stage  reforms  were  to  establish  the  urban  services  companies  (USCs)  with  more 
3. 
professional management and access to skilled staff. It was recognized, however, that increased 
pressure  to  reduce  USC  autonomy  would  be  likely.  Accordingly,  it  was  expected  that  service 
delivery  in  some  contexts  may  only  be  modest  and  not  sustainable  without  further  reforms  to 
better align incentives with service delivery. Performance-based management contracts or lease 
affermage arrangements with qualified private operators were seen as ways to further incentivize 
results. The establishment of USCs and further advisory support on private sector participation 
were to pave the way for second-stage reforms, with more comprehensive performance-based 
management contracts in solid waste management (SWM) and water services, and appropriate 
systems for regulation. 
 
B. 
 
4. 
According  to  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  (DMF)  for  tranche  1,  the  expected 
impact was improved health and, quality of life in and economic competitiveness of participating 
towns.  The  intended  outcome  was  increased  quality,  reliability,  and  coverage  of  water  supply, 
wastewater,  and  SWM  services  in  participating  towns.  The  intended  outputs  were  as  follows:   
Part  A:  urban  planning,  institutional  development,  and  program  implementation  support  for 
program  execution  and  institutional  reforms;  Part  B:  improved  water  supply  and  wastewater 
management to boost service coverage, quality, and reliability through civil works and equipment 
provision; Part C: improved SWM through civil works and equipment required for the construction 
and operation of sanitary landfill facilities, solid waste collection equipment, and communal waste 
bins; and Part D: operational and transition support funding to cover cash shortfalls in the newly 
established urban service companies—in advance of planned tariff increases—and greater cost 
recovery.  Parts  B  and  C  financed  physical  outputs:  (i)  increased  connections  to  piped  water 
supply  and  reduced  system  leakage,  (ii)  increased  wastewater  disposal  and  capacity  for 
wastewater  treatment,  and  (iii)  development  of  sanitary  landfills  and  increased  access  to  solid 
waste  collection.  Parts  A  and  D  financed  nonphysical  outputs:  (i)  improved  institutions  and 

                                                
1  Taluka is a district subdivision. 
2  ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche Financing 
Facility  and  Technical  Assistance  Grant  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Sindh  Cities  Improvement 
Investment Program. Manila. 

3  Footnote 2, para. 21. 
4  The MFF was a 10-year, $300 million investment for the Sindh Cities Improvement Investment Program with five 

tranches. 

  

3 

Provision of Inputs 

incentives for urban service delivery; (ii) capacity development for system planning, operations, 
and  maintenance;  (iii)  enhanced  cost  recovery  via  metering,  billing,  and  collection  tariffs;  and  
(iv) increased efficiency via predictable recurrent financing and performance-based contracting 
and private sector participation. 
 
C. 
 
5. 
The program’s tranche 1 was approved in December 2008 and became effective in March 
2009, 2 days earlier than planned.5  The closing date in March 2016 was significantly later than 
the targeted closing date in December 2012. Of the total $50 million, ADB was to finance 76% 
and the remainder by the Government of Sindh.  At completion, $49.1 million (98%) of tranche 1 
funds  were  used  with  ADB  financing  75%  and  the  balance  from  the  government.  The  project 
completion  report  (PCR)  indicated  that  the  scope  and  costs  of  tranche  1  for  the  SWM 
subcomponent  and  civil  works  on  water  and  sanitation  were  underestimated  at  appraisal. 6  
Civil  work  bids  were  higher  than  estimates  as  remote  locations  were  not  accounted  for.  
The 2-year implementation delay also led to cost increases. Accordingly, tranche 1 scope and 
outputs  were  reduced  and  contingencies  were  deployed.    At  appraisal,  civil  work  costs  were 
estimated at $11.4 million, which increased to $19.2 million at closure, and the overall scope of 
activities  decreased.  The  consultancy  cost  increased  by  18%  to  $6.8  million,  compared  to  the 
estimated $5.6 million. The full loan amount was not used as some works were not completed 
because of nonpayment to contractors due to tax and site handover issues.7   
 
6. 
Tranche 1 was classified as category B for involuntary resettlement and the environment, 
and  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples  Since  the  relevant  information  to  establish  material 
compliance (or lack thereof) cannot be obtained, the project’s adherence to ADB’s Safeguard on 
Involuntary Resettlement could not be assessed.8  The initial environmental examination reports 
and environmental management plans were prepared for all relevant subprojects. The program 
was supported by a $2.5 million technical assistance (TA) grant. It was envisaged that the TA 
grant would be implemented over 48 months, starting in December 2008. A total of 1,314 person-
month  contracts  was  awarded  to  international  and  national  individuals,  but  only  832  person-
months were used. The remainder was terminated because of limited absorption capacity of the 
North  Sindh  Urban  Services  Corporation  Limited  (NSUSC),  or  lack  of  consultants’  capacity  to 
deliver the required services.  

 
The  TA  grant  had  two  components:  Component  A  was  to  (i)  assist  with  information 
7. 
gathering,  (ii) 
improve  outsourcing 
arrangements,  and  (iv)  develop  and  implement  public–private  partnership  transactions;  and 

improvement  programs,  (iii) 

implement  operational 

                                                
5  ADB. 2017. Completion Report: Sindh Cities Improvement Investment Program–Tranche 1 in Pakistan. Manila. 
6  Footnote 5, para. 27. 
7  These include (i) construction of four water treatment plants (WTPs) in Sukkur and Khairpur, and (ii) construction of 

six distribution network improvement zones in four cities. 

8  Although the social impact assessments and resettlement planning in three land acquisition and resettlement plans 
information  disclosure,  consultation,  and  participation  at  project  preparation  for  landfill  sites  were  adequate,  the 
evaluation  of  LARP  implementation,  including  compensation,  assistance,  and  benefits  for  affected  persons  and 
handling  of  potential  grievances  were  not  possible.  The  project  documentation  did  not  provide  any  resettlement 
monitoring  reports.    During  the  project’s  course,  only  the  landfill  site  in  Khairpur  with  109  affected  people  was 
acquired.    The  land  for  the  remaining  two  sites  could  not  be  acquired  due  to  delayed  release  of  funds  by  the 
Government of Sindh. See Government of Sindh. 2008a. Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plan for the Khairpur 
Sanitary Landfill. Khairpur; Government of Sindh. 2008b. Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plan for the Sukkur 
Area Sanitary Landfill at Rohri. Sukkur; Government of Sindh. 2008c. Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plan for 
the  Shikarpur  Sanitary  Landfill.  Shikarpur;  and  ADB  (Independent  Evaluation  Department).  2018.  Safeguard 
Performance and ADB’s Safeguard Work Quality: Sindh Cities Improvement Investment Program. 8 June (internal). 

 4 

 

Implementation Arrangements 

Component B was to take care of (i) customer awareness of reforms in water supply, wastewater, 
and  SWM  services;  (ii)  communications  between  service  providers  and  customers;  
(iii) public monitoring of service delivery; (iv) accountability of service providers to the public; and 
(v) developing a customer care system.  However, the systems developed under the TA  grant 
were  not  implemented  due  to  frequent  turnover  of  NSUSC  staff  and  its  partner  TMAs,  
which contributed to a loss of the institutional memory and internal capacity required to maintain 
the systems.9 
 
D. 
 
8. 
The tranche 1 design envisaged to establish these three institutions: (i) program support 
unit (PSU), (ii) the urban unit, and (iii) the NSUSC. A program steering committee was formed 
under  the  Planning  and  Development  Department  (P&DD)  to  provide  policy  directions  and 
strategic oversight. It met at least once a year and served as the focal point for inter-coordination 
on implementation-related matters. These three institutions, although established, had significant 
issues.  The  TMAs  and  the  Local  Government,  Rural  Development  &  Housing,  Town  Planning 
institutional  arrangements.  Also,  
Department  (LGRD&HTPD)  were  not  included  in  the 
the  absence  of  well-defined  performance  benchmarks  and  service  standards  made  the 
contractual arrangement between the TMAs and the NSUSC inoperable. The arrangements also 
required  the  transfer  of  operational  and  capital  investment  planning  and  implementation 
responsibilities to NSUSC immediately, without allowing the new organization some time to grow. 
The selection of the P&DD through PSU as the tranche 1 executing agency dissociated it from 
mainstream local government functionaries and led to a lack of ownership within the participating 
TMAs. Coordination among the PSU, the urban unit, and NSUSC with LGRD&HTPD was weak 
because no tranche 1 component directly financed the LGRD&HTPD or the TMAs.   
 
9. 
Of the 70 covenants in the loan and the project agreement, 40 (59%) were complied with, 
23  (33%)  were  partly  complied  with,  five  (7%)  were  not  complied  with,  and  one  became  not 
applicable as an amendment in the project agreement approved in May 2012. The covenants that 
were  not  complied  with  pertained to (i)  insurance of  tranche  1 facilities, (ii)  putting  in  place  an 
enforcement mechanism for NSUSC, (iii) monitoring tranche 1 impacts on gender, (iv) disclosure 
of  the  procurement  process  on  the  website,  and  (v)  establishment  of  the  investment  program 
(IPPMS)  and  collecting  gender-disaggregated  data.  
performance  monitoring  system 
The covenant on policy actions and supporting studies were not complied with due to the reduced 
commitment  and  lack  of  funding  from  the  government.  The  operational  covenants  and 
requirements related to performance benchmarking, metering of water supplies, tariff revisions, 
outsourcing  of  different  functions  and/or  services,  and  effective  public  engagement  were  not 
complied with due to the (i) lack of capacity of the NSUSC, (ii) weak performance of consultants, 
(iii) weak program management unit oversight role, and (iv) interference of the NSUSC board of 
directors.  This  noncompliance  resulted  in  (i)  low  corporate  and  performance-based  culture  in 
NSUSC, (ii) unsustainable operations, (iii) absence of performance measurement and incentives 
to improve services, (iv) inability to engage private sector to increase efficiency of operations, and 
(v)  poor  public  and  stakeholder  perception  about  NSUSC  performance  due  to  ineffective 
communication and information dissemination. 
 
 
 

                                                
9  Some aspects of the TA grant, including the operational improvements program, communication with customers, 
outsourcing arrangements, and public–private partnership models, were not well-delivered due to the weak capacity 
of consultants. 

  

5 

II. 

EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE AND RATINGS 

institutional 

Relevance of Design and Formulation 

 
A. 
 
The PCR rated tranche 1 less than relevant. It was pertinent to Pakistan’s development 
10. 
objectives at appraisal and completion, particularly on the country’s medium-term development 
framework (2005–2010) and to Pakistan’s Vision 2030 and Framework for Economic Growth.10 
At  appraisal,  the  devolution  of  administration,  finances,  and  functions  to  elected  local 
governments was a major policy objective of the government. Under the Sindh Local Government 
Ordinance  (SLGO)  2001,  TMAs  were  entrusted  with  municipal  functions  but  related  financing, 
skills,  and  accountability  mechanisms  were  not  developed  nor  fully  devolved.11 The  program, 
including  tranche  1,  was  aligned  to  address  these  gaps  in  devolved  service  delivery  and  to 
strengthen  devolved  municipal  institutions  in  the  process.  It  was  also  consistent  with  the  ADB 
country strategy at appraisal and completion.12 It emphasized urban sector interventions, focusing 
improve  municipal  service  delivery. 13  
on 
to 
The  current  country  partnership  strategy  also  highlighted  institutional,  policy,  and  regulatory 
reforms as core components of any infrastructure investment to ensure the financially sustainable 
delivery of urban services.14 
 
11. 
The  RRP  argued  that  the  MFF  modality  is  well  suited  to  the  investment  program  as  it 
avoids the piecemeal approach of past urban sector projects and establishes a sufficiently broad 
platform over a 10-year period (para. 2). An adequate road map for the MFF was provided in the 
RRP.  But  tranche  1  was  constrained  by  the  lack  of  commitment  to  program  reforms,  and  the 
limited capacity of government agencies and supporting consultants, which led to (i) difficulties in 
achieving the targeted staffing levels in the NSUSC and PSU; (ii) indecisiveness on issues with 
contractors and taxes; (iii) inadequate estimation of problems with land acquisition for subprojects; 
(iv) slow counterpart payment releases by the government; (v) slow procurement, execution of 
civil works, and handover of subproject sites; (vi) slow recruitment and subsequent termination of 
design consultants due to poor performance; and (vii) delayed decisions of the NSUSC board of 
directors and the government on issues related to tranche 1 implementation.  

reform  and 

investments 

 

12.  Many of the reasons for the design failure were identified in the  DMF assumptions and 
risks, but were not addressed with effective mitigation strategies. For example, the new NSUSC 
was assigned two roles (infrastructure development and service delivery) from the outset, which 
was  beyond  its  capacity.  To  achieve  economies  of  scale,  tranche  1  was  active  in  six  cities,15 
overstretching  NSUSC’s  limited  resources.  The  geographic  scope  included  Larkana  and 
Shikarpur,  which  unlike the  other  four  cities,  had  no  tariff  base  to  allow  service  cost-recovery. 
Given its limited capacity, NSUSC‘s focus remained on capital works, with marginal effort toward 

                                                
10 Government  of  Pakistan,  Planning  Commission.  2011.  The  Framework  for  Economic  Growth.  Islamabad;  
and Government of Pakistan, Planning Commission. 2007. Vision 2030—Pakistan in the 21st Century. Islamabad.   

11 Government of Sindh. 2001. Sindh Local Government Ordinance 2001. Karachi. 
12 ADB. 1999. Urban Sector Strategy. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program Update: Pakistan, 2006–2008. Manila. 
14 ADB. 2015. Country Partnership Strategy: Pakistan, 2015–2019. Manila. 
15 The risks of choosing six tranche 1 cities from North Sindh were not well analyzed at design stage. Many politically 
influential Sindh residents were opposed to urban service companies—the political representatives of all cities except 
Sukkur  were  against  the  urban  reforms  and  the new  governance  structure  of  an  urban  service  company.  By  the 
second year of program implementation, the NSUSC had no political representation in North Sindh because elected 
mayors  were  replaced  with  the  administrators  in  participating  towns.  Most  nominated  board  members  were  from 
Karachi, with limited knowledge of and interest in North Sindh. The board interference and micromanagement also 
limited the NSUSC’s autonomy and ability to develop as envisaged. ADB sought to reduce the size of the board and 
improve its constitution, but this process was slow, influenced by the political elite of North Sindh. 

 6 

 

streamlining operations and assets, which was also one of its core functions. Financiers agreed 
to address these issues by restructuring NSUSC and returning responsibility for SWM partly to 
the TMA, but the indecisiveness of the government curtailed the impact of these improvements.   

 
This validation notes that the reforms and institutional model were not fully implemented 
13. 
mostly  because  of  commitment  issues,  which  had  been  identified  as  a  risk.  The  overall 
commitment of the government to devolved service delivery began to diminish in the middle of 
tranche 1 implementation. Elected mayors were replaced by TMA administrators, who became 
NSUSC  board  of  director  members  in  December  2009,  and  remained in their  positions for  the 
remainder  of  tranche  1.  The  aim  of  professional  urban  service  companies  was  to  replace 
inefficient TMA administration, provide them with representation in the board of directors and put 
them  in  a  position  to  directly  influence  the  reforms  that  were  undermining  their  role.  In  2010,  
the  government  began  to  progressively  centralize  the  previously  devolved  local  government 
functions by amending the SLGO. This sent strong signals against the reforms started under the 
investment program and undermined the role of the NSUSC.   

Effectiveness in Achieving Project Outcomes and Outputs 

 
This  validation  assesses  that  although  the  outcomes  were  aligned  with  country 
14. 
development  priorities  and  with  corresponding  ADB  country  and  corporate  strategies,  
the institutional arrangements designed were not feasible, thus, preventing the achievement of 
envisaged outputs. The tranche 1 design correctly identified many risks, however, the mitigation 
measures  proposed  in  the  design  were  inadequate,  and  no  major  changes  were  made  during 
implementation to mitigate these risks. This validation gives the program’s tranche 1 a rating of 
less than relevant. 
    
B. 
 
15. 
The PCR rated tranche 1 less than effective in achieving its intended outcome. However, 
this  validation  notes  that  the  PCR  used  revised  performance  targets,  where  the  duration  for 
achieving  the  outputs  was  increased,  in  the  assessment  of  effectiveness.  Despite  this,  
most outputs were not achieved even within the extended period. This validation also notes that 
the  inability  to  achieve outputs  and  outcomes  is  largely  attributable to foreseeable problems—
which were not adequately mitigated in the design. The first of the four outcome indicators and 
associated targets in the DMF was the population of participating towns with water connections 
was  to  be  increased  from  37%  in  2008  to  52%  in  2013—and  this  was  not  achieved  in  time.  
The PCR indicated that the low coverage may be partly due to massive urbanization following the 
2010 floods, particularly in Sukkur.16 The second was increasing the duration of water supply from 
3  hours  in  2008  to  more  than  6  hours  in  2013,  and  over  20  hours  for  18,000  households  in 
distribution  network  improvement  zones—and  this,  too,  was  not  achieved.17 The  third  was  for 
drainage  and  knock-on  water  quality  to  benefit  100,000  households  by  2013—which  was  not 
achieved  but  reflected  a  data  that  is  near  its  target,  a  year  later.18 The  fourth  was  increasing 
household access to SWM services to 80% by 2013 in participating towns—and this was partly 
achieved.19   
                                                
16 Treated water was supplied only to Khairpur city while Sukkur and Rohri received partially treated water as WTPs 
were  incomplete  at  the  time  of  tranche  1’s  closure.  Some  parts  of  Sukkur  received  treated  water  following  the 
completion  of  remnant  tranche  1  works  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  2016.  In  2017,  3,411  households  out  of  
5,596 households in four zones, which were connected to six distribution network improvement zones, were receiving 
potable water for 10–12 hours per day. 

17 The actual duration of water supply ranges from 0.5 hours to 12.0 hours in different locations. At PCR preparation, 
the average duration was around 4.0 hours in Rohri, and 2.1 hours in Khairpur. Data for Sukkur were not available.  

18 By 2014, 88,745 households were connected to the sewerage network. 
19 By  PCR  time,  the  secondary  solid  waste  management  services  were  up  to  72%.  However,  due  to  the  failure  to 

construct sanitary landfills, solid wastes were being dumped in available open spaces and private lands.  

  

7 

 
16. 
Service Management and Planning were as follows:  

On outputs, the status of achieving the performance targets in Part A: Improved Urban 

 
(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

 
(iv) 

 

the  creation  of  effective  and  sustainable  urban  services  providers,  
On 
(a)  establishment  of  a  sustainable  NSUSC  was  not  achieved; 20  
the 
(b) performance-based contracts between NSUSC and private operators for solid 
waste  collection  by  2014  was  not  achieved  and  no  activity  was  outsourced;  
(c) increase in recovery of operation and maintenance cost through user charges 
from 1% to at least 5% by 2014 was not achieved and even for fiscal year (FY) 
2015,  the  recovery  share  was  4%;  and  (d)  increased  share  of  connected 
households paying  water  bill  in participating towns  from  39%  in  2008 to 67%  in 
2014 was not assessed.  
 
On  the  establishment  of  urban  policy  and  strategic  planning  (urban)  unit,  
(a) a functioning and sustainable urban unit was set up by 2009, (b) the strategic 
urban vision was adopted by 2012, (c) planning processes for interior Sindh was 
done  by  2012,  and  (d)  digitized  maps  for  six  participating  towns  in  North  Sindh 
were publicly available by 2014.  
 
On having an effective support facility for TMA planning—urban plans for Sukkur 
and Larkana were submitted to P&DD by 2014. 

On having a timely and transparent operations support funding for NSUSC to cover 
eligible shortfall, (a) the NSUSC monthly staff payroll was met, and (b) payments 
to NSUSC suppliers as agreed were partly achieved.   

 
17. 
None of the output performance targets were achieved in Part B: Investments in Water 
Supply and Wastewater Management Improvements as the following were noted: (i) the extent of 
households with connections were lower than expected, duration of water availability was lower, 
and wastewater treatment was not up to expectation (para. 15); and (ii) 6,000 households in Rohri 
did not have improved water supply at intake by 2014, and the planned treatment of wastewater 
being disposed upstream, or the shifting of wastewater disposal downstream of the Rohri intake 
were  not  executed.  For  Part  C:  Investments  in  Solid  Waste  Management  Improvements,  
the  output  performance  targets  were  not  achieved  as  (i)  the  development  of  landfill  sites  was 
dropped following the midterm review; and (ii) the share of solid waste collected increasing to an 
average from 19% in 2008 to at least 80% by 2014 was not achieved, while on average, 55% of 
the 1,094 million tons was collected by FY2015.21 
 
18. 
The outcomes of investments in different types of infrastructure were interdependent but 
sequencing  and  prioritizing  of  investments  during  design  stage  did  not  recognize  this 
interdependence. Similarly, changes were made in tranche 1 costs to meet shortfalls in the civil 
works,  construction  supervision,  and  operations,  primarily  by  reallocating  contingencies.  
This  reduced  the  commitment  to  cost  recovery  improvements,  performance,  and  operational 
efficiency of NSUSC and the government.    

                                                
20 Although the NSUSC was established as an institution, it  struggled to attain technical and financial sustainability.  
In March 2017, the Supreme Court of Pakistan ordered the NSUSC disbanded and municipal functions returned to 
the participating TMAs. 

21 The collection percentage varied from 45% to 90% in various towns. 

 8 

 

Efficiency of Resource Use 

Tranche 1 was classified as category B for involuntary resettlement and the environment, 
19. 
and  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  One  landfill  site  in  Khairpur  without  structures  and 
productive use was acquired. The 109 affected people from the land acquisition and resettlement 
plans were paid according to their entitlements and no complaints were received. The land for the 
remaining two sites could not be acquired due to the delayed release of funds by the government. 
The housekeeping measures were managed according to the environmental management plans. 
However, the reports were not updated to capture changes in program scope, and the impact of 
increased water supplies on drainage and sewerage. Also, the government and NSUSC did not 
comply  with  the  covenant  to  monitor  the  impact  of  each  subproject  on  women  during 
implementation.  An  IPPMS  was  not  developed  and  monitoring  of  the  subproject  impacts  on 
women  was  not  undertaken. 22 There  was  inadequate  attention  to  gender  action  plan  (GAP) 
design and monitoring. As none of the outcome targets was achieved and only some of output 
targets were realized, this validation rates tranche 1 ineffective.  
 
C. 
 
The  PCR  rated  tranche  1  less  than  efficient  mainly  because  economic  and  financial 
20. 
analyses  were  not  undertaken  at  completion  due  to  (i)  physical  works  being  incomplete,  
(ii)  NSUSC  being  disbanded  before  project  completion  review,  (iii)  transfer  of  ownership  of  all 
assets  created  by  NSUSC  to  the  TMAs,23 (iv)  no  service  tariff  increase  was  reported  in  any 
participating city, and (v) the volumetric tariff was not implemented. In the absence of financial 
and economic data, it was not possible to undertake an economic and financial analyses for even 
the completed subprojects. Tranche 1 was delayed by 2 years and out of the 13 civil works and 
supply  contracts,  four  major  water  supply  treatment  and  distribution  contracts  remained 
incomplete  by  loan  closing.  Of  these  four,  the  two  major  international  contracts  were  90% 
complete  at  loan  closure  and  were  completed  under  tranche  2  of  the  program.  Therefore,  
this validation rates tranche 1 inefficient.   
 
D. 
 
21. 
undertaken  for  the  reasons  given  above.  The  institutional  sustainability  is  also  uncertain.   
In March 2017, the Supreme Court of Pakistan, after hearing a constitutional petition about poor 
service delivery of urban services across Sindh, ordered the NSUSC disbanded, and municipal 
functions returned to the participating TMAs, with an administrative order issued in April 2017. 
There  is  insufficient  evidence  that  political  risks  will  diminish  (para.  33).  Environmental 
sustainability is possible and people in the participating cities started incrementally benefiting from 
the  tranche  1  facilities  as  wastewater  disposal  system  and  solid  waste  collection  coverage 
improves. A water treatment plant in Khairpur started providing treated water to half of the city at 
completion and two water treatment plants in Sukkur started providing treated water 2 years after 
tranche  1  completion.  While  it  is  possible  that  these  assets  will  continue  to  operate,  
albeit suboptimally, through subsidies provided by the government and TMAs; but with extremely 
low tariffs and recovery, inefficient operations with poor performance parameters and incentives, 
and the disbanding of NSUSC, it is unlikely that operation of the assets created in tranche 1 will 
be sustained. This validation rates tranche 1 unlikely sustainable.   

The  PCR  rated  tranche  1  less  than  likely  sustainable.  Financial  analysis  was  not 

Preliminary Assessment of Sustainability  

                                                
22 Footnote 5. Appendix 7 provides an update on the GAP and records very limited GAP scope and achievements.  
23 Due to political unrest in the project area, the premature closure of NSUSC, and long delay in the payment of staff 
salaries who were transferred back to TMAs, the financial data of the TMAs remained unavailable at the time of the 
project completion review. 

  

9 

III. 

OTHER PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENTS 

Preliminary Assessment of Development Impact 

 
A. 
 
The PCR rated the impact of tranche 1 less than satisfactory. Tranche 1 was expected to 
22. 
increase per capita monthly income in interior Sindh by 2018 from the baseline of PRs1,446 in 
2008.  According  to  secondary  data,  the  average  monthly  per  capita  income  had  increased 
substantially to PRs4, 545 in 2016.24  However, no direct link to the substantial increase in monthly 
per capita income could be established with tranche 1 investments. The PCR also noted that the 
prevalence of diarrhea in children under 5 years of age was reduced from 19% in 200525 to 8.9% 
in 2016, which is below the target of 10%.26 
 
This validation also notes that the link between secondary data on income and health care 
23. 
and tranche 1, which had incomplete outputs, is weak. A customer report card survey conducted 
at  completion  was  compared  with  a  similar  survey  conducted  at  the  start  of  tranche  1,  
and the results were related to the level of tranche 1 investment in each sector and town. Data 
show a direct relationship between per household investment in water supply services and the 
number of customers dissatisfied with the water service. The number of dissatisfied customers 
decreased as household investment in water supply increased. Similar trends were observed in 
other services. Primary and secondary collection increased for solid waste quantities, but with no 
final disposal option, environmental gains achieved in one part of the city were offset by negative 
impacts on the health of people elsewhere due to unsanitary disposal. 

 

(ii)  outsourcing  and 

24.  Moreover,  the  foundation  for  the  expected  range  of  MFF  impacts  has  not  been  laid  as 
capacities for city planning, management, and urban service delivery have not been enhanced. 
Although the quality, continuity, and coverage of water supply, wastewater, and SWM services 
were improved and are now better managed, investment is still required to improve operations 
and maintenance management. Enhancements are also needed in (i) managerial and technical 
introducing  performance-based  management  contracts;  
capacity; 
(iii)  cost  recovery  and  service  revenues;  (iv)  building  awareness;  (v)  linking  the  levels  of 
infrastructure investment, service delivery performance, and user charges; (vi) financial planning 
for urban service providers’ budgeting, monitoring, and reporting; (vii) customer orientation and 
developing informed and responsible customers; and (viii) leveraging private sector expertise to 
improve service delivery. This validation rates development impact less than satisfactory. 
 
B. 
 
25. 
The  PCR  rated  the  performance  of  the  borrower  and  the  PSU  less  than  effective.  
The commitment of the government to continue reforms after the first 2 years of implementation 
declined substantially. There were major delays in the release of operational funds to NSUSC. 
The government could not appoint the heads of the urban unit and PSU through open competition. 
                                                
24 Pakistan Bureau of Statistics. Household Integrated Economic Survey, 2015–2016.  
    http://www.pbs.gov.pk/content/household-integrated-economic-survey-hies-2015-16. 
25  Government  of  Sindh,  Planning  and  Development  Department.  2017.  Completion  Report  of  Sindh  Cities 

Performance of the Borrower and Executing Agency 

Improvement Investment Program–Tranche 1. Karachi. 

26 The cases of diarrhea in children under 5 years of age have declined from levels prevalent in 2012 in the towns 
where investments were made in water supply improvement. With the exception of New Sukkur (where the WTP 
was not completed), the reduction in diarrhea cases is directly proportional to the level of investment in water supply 
subprojects.  Data  also  show  that  in  Shikarpur,  where  no  water  supply  investment  was  made,  cases  of  diarrhea 
increased from 55,607 in 2012 to 60,626 in 2015. Similarly, the prevalence of diarrhea per household in Shikarpur, 
where inhabitants use own-source water, is 10 times higher than in towns where the public water supply system was 
improved under tranche1. 

 10 

 

Performance of the Asian Development Bank and Cofinanciers 

It was unable to control delays and manage key appointments. The management of PSU and the 
urban unit changed more than four times from 2009 to 2014, and senior bureaucrats appointed 
by  the  government  (which  is  a  conflict  of  interest)  headed  both  organizations  for  a  significant 
period  of  time.  These  actions  delayed  implementation,  affected  the  quality  of  operations,  and 
tainted  the  reputation  of  NSUSC.  The  PSU  did  not  establish  a  working  relationship  with  key 
stakeholders  during  program  implementation.  Its  key  implementation  role  was  to  monitor  and 
evaluate NSUSC performance and results, almost as a de facto regulator, but PSU was unable 
to perform this important role, and all business and operational plans of NSUSC were approved 
without effective performance indicators and service and cost standards. This validation rates the 
performance of the borrower and PSU less than satisfactory. 
 
C. 
 
26. 
The  PCR  rated  the  performance  of  ADB  less  than  effective.  ADB  provided  support  to 
speed up the procurement process after observing a growing backlog and lack of capacity within 
NSUSC  and  the  consultants  to  manage  the  procurement  process.  ADB  carried  out  14  review 
missions  during  tranche  1  implementation.  It  is  noted  that  in  the  review  mission  of  February–
March  2011,  ADB  recognized  the  magnitude  of  the  problems  facing  the  reform  program  and 
encouraged action to facilitate the reforms.27  The PCR indicated that the design of tranche 1 was 
complex and ADB largely micromanaged implementation for the initial 2 years. This kept tranche 
1 on track, reduced external interference, but also fostered dependency that slowed the growth 
and development of NSUSC. It also indicated that there were no changes made in the tranche 1 
design  (except  fund  flow  procedures)  to  address  design  gaps  that  hampered  tranche  1 
performance.  ADB  was  unable  to  take  meaningful  steps  to  enforce  loan  covenants  on  critical 
issues,  such  as  competitive  recruitment,  transfer  of  funds  to  NSUSC  for  staff  salaries  and 
operations, performance-based budgeting of NSUSC, and establishment of an IPPMS.  It is also 
noted that ADB had gained experience in Pakistan and that experience in the water supply and 
other  municipal  services  sector  had  been  less  than  successful. 28  Lessons  from  these 
interventions should have been applied to the design of this MFF. This validation gives a rating of 
less than satisfactory. 
 
D. 
 
27. 
At program design and appraisal, the Operations Evaluation Department assessed ADB’s 
urban  sector  lending  in  Pakistan  as  weak,  citing  limited  ability  to  “turn  physical  outputs  into 
outcomes.”  The  reasons  included  were  (i)  financial  and  management  weakness  of  urban 
authorities,  (ii)  poor  sequencing  of  infrastructure  and  resulting  weak  institutional  reforms,  
(iii)  distortions  from  rent-seeking  behavior,  and  (iv)  too  little  innovation  and  private  sector 
participation.29  Although the program design directly addressed these issues by providing a given 
TMA a sound alternative to professionally manage urban services delivery—through a jointly held 
company—the feasibility of doing this in Sindh was not adequately considered. The program’s 
intention  to  go  beyond  institutional  strengthening  components  to  ensure  that  key  institutional 

Others 

                                                
27 ADB  (Central and West  Asia  Department). 2011.  Review  Mission  to  India:  Sindh  Cities  Improvement Investment 
Program.  Back-to-office  report.  21  March  (internal).  The  mission  noted  that  “There  remains  extensive  scope  for 
engaging with political leaders, the media, the private sector, and other civil society groups and local communities to 
educate on SCIP and regionally structured, professional utility companies to deliver water and sanitation services.” 
This suggests that there was inadequate attention to program readiness.

reform  is  in  place  upfront  was  logical,  but  the  political  context  in  Sindh  was  not  understood 
adequately enough to facilitate an acceptable reform process. 
 

IV. 

OVERALL ASSESSMENT, LESSONS, AND RECOMMENDATIONS 

Overall Assessment and Ratings 

 
A. 
 
28. 
The  PCR  rated  the  tranche  1  of  the  program  less  than  successful.  This  validation  rates 
tranche 1 less than relevant, ineffective, inefficient, and unlikely sustainable—resulting in an overall 
assessment of unsuccessful. While tranche 1 was consistent with its policy context, the design was 
seriously flawed despite adequately identifying critical risks. No outcome targets were achieved and 
the output achievements were mixed along with weak GAP analysis. The economic internal rate of 
return  analysis  could  not  be  calculated  and  there  were  significant  process  delays.  The  rating  of 
unlikely  sustainable  is  given  in  the  absence  of  financial  internal  rate  of  return  analysis  and  on 
institutional, environmental, and social grounds.

 12 

 

Lessons 

B. 
 
29. 
Project-level lessons. The PCR identified several  project-level lessons on the phased 
approach  to  transferring  work  to  NSUSC,  anchoring  the  program’s  tranche  1  with  the  local 
government,  restricting the  investment  to  a  fewer  cities,  signing  a  service  agreement  between 
TMAs and NSUSC, and having adequate a priori analysis on private sector participation. 30 
 
30. 
Country-level  lesson.  The  experience  of  tranche  1  suggests  the  lack  of  readiness  for 
implementation.  The  ADB  mission  in  February–March  2011  suggests  an  inadequate  policy 
dialogue  before  and  during  MFF  preparation  (footnote  27).  The  significant  risks  identified  at 
appraisal should have led to examining the mitigation strategies with the government (para. 12). 

 
Results framework and methodology-level lessons. The non-establishment of a project 
31. 
performance  management  system  is  unacceptable.  The  covenant  on  the  establishment  of  the 
IPPMS  was  very  clear.  Another  lesson  is  that  changing  performance  targets  and  due  dates 
midstream is not warranted.  

Recommendations for Follow-Up  

 
32. 
ADB  had  gained  experience  in  Pakistan’s  municipal  services  sector  and  these  were 
recorded  in  past  PCRs  and  country  assistance  program  evaluations.    Except  for  the  successful 
Punjab Community Water Supply and Sanitation Project, available PCRs rated ADB’s interventions 
less than successful, including the recent experience with the Megacity Development Project in the 
Sindh  province  (footnote  28).  Lessons  from  these  experiences  could  have  been  applied  to  the 
design of this MFF. 
 
C. 
 
33. 
In  Sindh  province,  the  majority  of  urban  reforms  initiated  in  2001—and  on  which  the 
program was based—have been undone, either by the Government of Sindh through changes in 
SLGO,  or  more  recently  through  decisions  of  the  Pakistan  Supreme  Court.  The  government 
currently has no clear urban policy direction or road map to manage and harness urban growth 
potential.  There is an urgent need to examine the Supreme Court decision and the government 
response. In the short to medium term, no new programs or investments are recommended in 
Sindh until there is greater clarity on an urban sector policy. However, there is a need to closely 
follow  up  and  guide  the  transition  of  services  back  to  the  TMAs  and  other  government 
departments.  In  addition,  further  tranches  implemented  under  this  investment  program  should 
diligently consider the lessons identified in the PCR and in this validation. 
 

V. 

OTHER CONSIDERATIONS AND FOLLOW-UP 

Monitoring and Reporting 

 
A. 
 
34. 
Factors essential for establishing the foundation of the reform program were not fully in 
place during tranche 1 design and were not followed up during its implementation. Generating 
baseline  data  and  mapping  existing  systems  was  a  priority  activity  to  establish  targets  and  to 
evaluate NSUSC and TMA performance. This was not addressed during implementation. 
  
 
 
      

                                                
30 Footnote 5, paras. 55–59. 

  

13 

Comments on Project Completion Report Quality 

B. 
 
35. 
This validation finds the quality of the PCR less than satisfactory. The PCR used revised 
performance indicators, which is not permitted (para. 15) and interchangeably used the results of 
both tranches 1 and 2 for the performance of tranche 1. Substantiation of the given ratings was 
not  adequate;  and  the  effectiveness,  efficiency,  and  sustainability  ratings  were  downgraded  in 
this validation. 
 
C. 
 
36. 
This validation is based on reviews of the RRP, PCR, appraisal and loan review mission 
reports,  midterm  review  mission  reports,  strategy  documents,  and  IED’s  project  safeguard 
assessment. 
 
D. 
 
37. 

It is recommended that the project be revisited after the completion of the MFF.

I.
PROJECT DESCRIPTION
A.
Rationale
1.
At appraisal, Sindh’s second-tier cities were under increasing stress of population growth
and urban  poverty.  Deteriorating  urban services added  to  business  costs,  damaged the  urban
environment,  diminished  the  quality  of  life,  and  discouraged  potential  investment.  Previous
attempts  to  improve  the  provision  of  services  were  hindered  by  overlap  and  fragmentation  of
